title: Diploma in Mathematics for Business Studies
headline: A free online course on polynomial functions, derivatives, and how to use sigma notation in an average formula.
description: Do you want to learn how to solve and graph polynomial equations? This course on mathematics for business studies teaches you the dominant rules of differentiation, trigonometric functions, and finding derivatives. Sign up today and develop your business math skills by mastering how the definite integral is distributed to a sum or how to calculate the difference of functions.

courseDescription:
This course explains the concept of polynomial functions and methods of integration. It takes you through the methods used to find the zeros of a polynomial function. You will also be introduced to the method used to draw a polynomial equation graph and find a polynomial function equation. Study the concept of rate of change together with the methods used in finding the slope of the tangent to a curve then learn about derivations, differentiability, and continuity. This course teaches you the essential techniques covered by the intermediate value theorem. You will study the differentiation rules, derivations of trigonometric functions, and the procedure used for differentiating a parametrized curve. Higher-order derivatives will also be covered as well as the application and differentiation of implicit functions.

Taking this course will provide you with the knowledge of the derivations of functions and the procedures for finding derivatives using logarithmic differentiation. You will be taught about the applications of the derivative in real-life problems. Learn about the linear approximations, the concept of Newton's method, and the application of the L'Hopital rule. Study the expansion of a binomial in addition to the application and the proof of the power rule. You will also study the applications and methods used to prove the rule for keeping a multiplicative constant. Do you know how to carry out the conversion process from rectangular to polar coordinates? The course shows you how to represent an odd number, dummy variable and how to use sigma notation to write an average formula. It also explains how to list the first four terms of sequence and the monotonic behaviour of a sequence. If you have struggled with understanding the properties and laws of the definite integral, then this course is for you.

Furthermore, you will also learn how to use the mathematical induction technique and the representation of the sigma sum. This course takes you through the use of Riemann sums with subintervals to estimate the distance travelled by a particle whose velocity is given. You will also learn how to reconfigure the integral in terms, as well as the natural exponential functions. Do you know how to list the first four terms of sequence and the monotonic behaviour of a sequence? This course will help you get a better understanding of the counting trick of counting ordered partitions of n. It explains in detail the steps required in finding the area under a curve, as well as the calculus techniques that can be employed to solve ancient problems of calculating complex areas. Create your account and enrol for free!

Start Course Now

Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:

  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.

  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.

  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module discusses the polynomial functions and the procedures used in finding zeros of a polynomial function. This module also outlines the methods used in graphing and finding the equation of a polynomial function.
topics: Graphs of Polynomial Functions - Learning Outcomes
Finding Zeros of a Polynomial Function
Finding the Equation of a Polynomial Function
Graphs of Polynomial Functions - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explains the rate of change together and the techniques used in finding the slope of a curve at a point. This module also explains derivations, differentiability, and continuity, and the applications of the intermediate value theorem.
topics: Rate of Change and Slope to a Curve

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module discusses the power rule along with the sum and difference rule. This module also analyses the derivations of trigonometric functions and implicit differentiation. Composite functions and the chain rule will also be discussed in this module.
topics: Composite Functions and the Chain Rule

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module analyses the inverse trigonometric functions and the derivatives of logarithmic functions. This module discusses the logarithmic differentiation and the applications of the derivatives. Linear approximations and Newton's method will also be covered in this module.
topics: Derivatives of Inverse Trigonometric Functions - Learning Outcomes
Derivatives of Inverse Trigonometric Functions - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Mathematics for Business Studies - First Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Mathematics for Business Studies - First Assessment

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about formulas that can be used to conveniently compress large sums together and the method required in estimating with Riemann sums and rectangular. Study Trapezoidal approximation methods and application of distance travelled and the area under a curve analysis.
topics: First Fundamental Theorem of Integral Calculus

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Study the method of integration by partial fractions that can be used and how to decompose a fractional integrand into the sum of simpler fractions. Learn about the power rule for integration and integration by u-substitution. Study the integrating natural logarithmic functions together with integrating natural exponential functions.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Learn about the triangular sequences, geometric sequence, binary sequence along with the power and arithmetic sequence. You will also learn about the finite sequence, the sigma laws, factorial notation together with the formulas for sums of sequences.
topics: Sigma Notation and Variable Number of Terms

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module will teach you the divergent test for geometric series and how to find the coefficient. Discuss the methods of determining whether or not an infinite series converges a comparison test. Study about the interval and radius of convergence of a power series.
topics: Ratio Test and Alternating Series Test

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Mathematics for Business Studies - Second Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Mathematics for Business Studies - Second Assessment

topics: -  Diploma in Mathematics for Business Studies - Final Graded Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the definition and degree of the polynomial function
    • Analyze the cases used to show the domain and range of a polynomial function.
    • Discuss the principles used in finding zeros of a polynomial function.
    • Analyze the possible end behaviors of a polynomial function.
    • Outline the steps needed to draw a reasonable polynomial equation graph.
    • Describe the graphing of a polynomial function by using transformers.
    • Explain the approaches used in finding the equation of a Polynomial Function.
    • Explain the conjugate root theorems as well as the special techniques for 2nd and 3rd-degree polynomials.
  • Introduction to Polynomial Functions
  • Definition of a Polynomial Function
  • A function which is of the form: P(x) = an xn + a{n-1} x{n-1} + ... + a1x + a0, where an, a{n-1}, ... a1, a0 are real numbers and n is a non-negative integer is said to be a polynomial or a polynomial function. It can also be called a polynomial in x or a polynomial function in x.

    The following are some examples of polynomial functions:
    • P(x) = 5x2 + 6x + 4
    • Q(x) = 6
    • R(x) = -3x4 - 2x + 7
    • F(x) = 2x5 - 4x4 + x3 + x2 -10 
  • Degree of a Polynomial Function
  • If P(x) is a polynomial, the highest power of x in P(x) is called the degree of the polynomial. As we have seen in the definition, polynomials are usually written in descending order of the powers of the variable. When written in this fashion, the power of the first term will indicate the degree of the polynomial.

  • Finding Zeros of a Polynomial Function
  • Introduction
  • This section will start to search for the zeros of more advanced polynomial functions. We will see that polynomials can often be manipulated, using principles we already know, to yield solutions to equations of the form: P(x) = 0.

    In future chapters, we will discover additional tools to solve polynomial equations that are not subject to the analysis in this section.

    Since we have had a great deal of practice solving linear and quadratic polynomial equations in the Algebra I and Algebra II courses, we will focus our attention here on more challenging quadratic equations as well as cubic and fourth-degree equations that will yield to the methods outlined below.
  • It is useful to remember that if P is a polynomial function and r is a real number for which P(r) = 0, then the following statements are equivalent:
    • r is a real zero of the polynomial function, P.
    • r is an x-intercept of the graph of P.
    • (x - r) is a factor of P.
    • r is a solution of the equation: P(x) = 0.

  • Graphing Polynomial Functions
  • In keeping with the notion that "a picture is worth a thousand words", we should be able to get a better idea of the behavior of polynomial functions by examining their graphs. Since we have already studied the graphs of first-degree polynomials (lines) and second-degree polynomials (parabolas) in earlier courses, we would like to focus our attention on techniques of graphing polynomial functions of degree greater than two.

    We have seen, in the past, that if we simply create a table of values for a function by selecting points at random, and then "connect the dots" we may or may not include the most important features of the function we are attempting to graph. For example, when graphing a parabola, we took the trouble to locate its axis of symmetry, which then gave us a way of getting the vertex or turning point of the parabola. By creating a table of values with the vertex as the center, and by locating the y-intercept of the parabola and any real zeros that might exist, we were assured of showing the essential features of this graph.

    So, how do we tackle the job of graphing a polynomial of a higher degree? Where the polynomial lends itself to analysis along the lines of this section, drawing its graph should not be a terribly difficult undertaking. If the polynomial is too complex to be analyzed here, we will tackle it again in future sections, when we have even more methods for unlocking its behavior. However, we will still follow the analysis below.
  • Aim: To graph a polynomial function, P(x) = anxn + a{n-1}x{n-1} +...+ a1x + a0, where a_n\neq0.

    We have seen, in the past, that if we simply create a table of values for a function by selecting points at random, and then "connect the dots" we may or may not include the most important features of the function we are attempting to graph. For example, when graphing a parabola, we took the trouble to locate its axis of symmetry, which then gave us a way of getting the vertex or turning point of the parabola. By creating a table of values with the vertex as the center, and by locating the y-intercept of the parabola and any real zeros that might exist, we were assured of showing the essential features of this graph.

    So, how do we tackle the job of graphing a polynomial of a higher degree? Where the polynomial lends itself to analysis along the lines of this section, drawing its graph should not be a terribly difficult undertaking. If the polynomial is too complex to be analyzed here, we will tackle it again in future sections, when we have even more methods for unlocking its behavior. However, we will still follow the analysis below.
  • Aim: To graph a polynomial function, P(x) = anxn + a{n-1}x{n-1} +...+ a1x + a0, where a_n\neq0.

  • Finding the Equation of a Polynomial Function
  • We have seen how to find zeros of polynomial functions, in those instances where we can reduce the polynomial to linear or quadratic factors, using methods learned in previous algebra courses. We will, in subsequent sections, learn additional techniques for finding the zeros of higher degree polynomials.

    In this section, we would like to reverse the process, that is to work our way back from the zeros to the equation of the polynomial. We will be recreating polynomial functions using two different approaches:
    • Finding the equation of a polynomial function, given its zeros.
    • Finding the equation of a polynomial function, given its graph.
  • Linear polynomial: The zero of the linear polynomial = -(Constant term)/Coefficient of x
  • Quadratic polynomial: Sum of its zeroes = -(Coefficient of x)/Coefficient of x2

    Product of its zeroes = Constant term/Coefficient of x2
  • Cubic polynomial: Sum of the zeroes = -(Coefficient of x2)/Coefficient of x3

    Product of the zeroes = -Constant term/Coefficient of x3

    The sum of the products of the zeroes taken two at a time = Coefficient of x/Coefficient of x3

  • Finding the Equation of a Polynomial Function
  • We have seen how to find zeros of polynomial functions, in those instances where we can reduce the polynomial to linear or quadratic factors, using methods learned in previous algebra courses. We will, in subsequent sections, learn additional techniques for finding the zeros of higher degree polynomials.

    In this section, we would like to reverse the process, that is to work our way back from the zeros to the equation of the polynomial. We will be recreating polynomial functions using two different approaches:
    • Finding the equation of a polynomial function, given its zeros.
    • Finding the equation of a polynomial function, given its graph.
  • Linear polynomial: The zero of the linear polynomial = -(Constant term)/Coefficient of x
  • Quadratic polynomial: Sum of its zeroes = -(Coefficient of x)/Coefficient of x2

    Product of its zeroes = Constant term/Coefficient of x2
  • Cubic polynomial: Sum of the zeroes = -(Coefficient of x2)/Coefficient of x3

    Product of the zeroes = -Constant term/Coefficient of x3

    The sum of the products of the zeroes taken two at a time = Coefficient of x/Coefficient of x3

  • Lesson Summary
    • A function which is of the form: P(x) = an xn + a{n-1} x{n-1} + ... + a1x + a0, where an, a{n-1}, ... a1, a0 are real numbers and n is a non-negative integer is said to be a polynomial or a polynomial function.
    • If P(x) is a polynomial, the highest power of x in P(x) is called the degree of the polynomial.
    • The domain of any polynomial function is the set of all real numbers.
    • If a polynomial function is of odd degree, its range will be all real numbers.
    • A polynomial function, P(x) of degree n, n  1, has at most n real zeros.
    • The behavior of the graph of a polynomial function P(x) as x approaches positive or negative infinite values is called the end behavior of the polynomial function.
    • There are four possible end behaviors that a polynomial function will assume, depending on the sign of the leading coefficient and whether the power of the first term is even or odd.
    • A turning point is a point of the graph where the graph changes from increasing to decreasing (rising to falling) or decreasing to increasing (falling to rising).
    • Finding the y-intercept of a polynomial function is, by far, the easier task. This is found by replacing x in the polynomial equation P(x) by zero. The x-intercepts of a polynomial function are the real zeros of the polynomial function. They are found by solving the equation P(x) = 0.
    • Conjugate root theorem I: If the polynomial has rational coefficients and if there is a root of the form, a+ b} , then there must also be a root of the form, a - b} .
    • Conjugate root theorem II: If there is a root of the form, a + b i then there must also be a root of the form, a - bi.

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Analyze the average and instantaneous rate of change.
    • Discuss the methods used in finding the slope of a curve at a point.
    • Discuss how to find the equation of the normal line of a curve at a given point.
    • Analyze the definition of a derivative and notation.
    • Outline the applications of Differentiability and Continuity.
    • Explain the Intermediate Value Theorem
  • The Derivative
  • You are driving to work. The distance from your home is changing with time. If you left home at 7 am, drove 90 miles to work, and arrived at 8:30, your average speed was 60 mph. Did you burst out of your garage at 60 mph? Were you doing 60 when you entered the parking lot at work? I hope not!!!

    60 mph was your average speed. Your speed varied over the course of your trip. Now if you hit a pothole, an auto mechanic might ask you how fast you were going at the moment you hit the pothole. He isnt interested in your average speed, but at your speed at a particular instant! How do we calculate this?

    As you will see, when one variable quantity, y, depends on another, x, the derivative will tell us the instantaneous rate of change of y with respect to x. The quantities might be distance and time (as in the above pothole example above), momentum and velocity, financial assets and time, air pressure, and height, to name just a few examples. The pairs of variable quantities that the derivative deals with are too numerous to list.

    The mathematical idea of the derivative was developed in the 17th century and revolutionized science! It is used in all the sciences (especially physics!), theoretical and applied mathematics, finance, economics, and engineering, to name a few subjects.

    The derivative is a pillar of the calculus. In order to calculate the derivative, we depend on the concept of limits.

  • Normal to a Curve
  • The normal line to a curve at a given point P is the line through P which is perpendicular to the tangent line at that point. In other words, the tangent line and normal line form a right angle at P. If the slope of the tangent line to the curve y = f(x) at the point P is m, and if m  0, then the slope of the normal line through P is the negative reciprocal of m, namely, - 1/m.
  • On the other hand, if the tangent line at P is horizontal, its slope is 0. The slope of the normal line is undefined there! Uh-oh, Don't panic. If the slope of a line is undefined, then the line is vertical. Aha! So, in this case, the normal line is vertical. If we know that the x-coordinate of P is x0, then the equation of the normal line through P is simply x = x0.

    Case closed!
  • Getting back to the case where the tangent line is not horizontal, it is then simple to find the equation of the normal line at P, since we will know the slope and the coordinates, (x0, y0) of P. Of course, we will need the point-slope formula for the equation of any line if its slope is m, and it contains the point (x0, y0): y-y0=m(x-x0).
  • Normal to a Curve
  • The normal line to a curve at a given point P is the line through P which is perpendicular to the tangent line at that point. In other words, the tangent line and normal line form a right angle at P. If the slope of the tangent line to the curve y = f(x) at the point P is m, and if m  0, then the slope of the normal line through P is the negative reciprocal of m, namely, - 1/m.
  • On the other hand, if the tangent line at P is horizontal, its slope is 0. The slope of the normal line is undefined there! Uh-oh, Don't panic. If the slope of a line is undefined, then the line is vertical. Aha! So, in this case, the normal line is vertical. If we know that the x-coordinate of P is x0, then the equation of the normal line through P is simply x = x0.

    Case closed!

  • Lesson Summary
    • The average rate of change of a quantity is the amount that it changes divided by the time it takes to incur that change.
    • The instantaneous rate of change with respect to the time of a changing quantity is the rate at which it is changing at a specific instant of time.
    • The formula below yields the slope of a line even though we only have knowledge of one point on this line!

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • The normal line to a curve at a given point P is the line through P which is perpendicular to the tangent line at that point.
    • The process we used to obtain m{tangent} for y = f(x) is called differentiation, since we take the limit of a difference quotient y/x.
    • The new function of x, derived from the original function by the process of differentiation is called the derivative and denoted f'(x) to distinguish it from the original function f(x).
    • The formula for the derivative is:

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Analyze the expansion of a Binomial and the proof of the power rule.
    • Discuss the application, along with the proof of major differentiation rules.
    • Analyze the derivations of the sine and cosine functions.
    • Outline the derivatives of other trigonometric functions.
    • Describe the constructs and applications of a composite function.
    • Discuss the procedure used for differentiating a parametrized curve.
    • Analyze the application of implicit functions and implicit differentiation
  • The Power Rule
  • Expanding a Binomial - Pascal's Triangle

    Pascals Triangle is a triangular array of numbers. The entries of its nth row yield the coefficients of the expansion of (a + b)n. Behold the first seven rows:

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • The second entry in each row tells us which row we are in.
    • Each entry is the sum of the two entries immediately above it. Thus, for example, the first 21 in the seventh row is the sum of the 6 and the 15 directly above it.
    • The triangle goes on forever, each row generated by the previous one using the procedure.

  • The Sum and Difference Rule
  • Suppose we know the derivatives of f(x) and g(x), and wish to compute the derivative of their sum. In other words (and symbols), what is y' if y = f(x) + g(x)? Why stop at two terms? What about y = f(x) + g(x) + h(x)?

    Differentiation may be distributed to each term of a function in a sum or difference expression.
  • Sum and Difference Rule rule:

    If y = f(x) + g(x), then y' = f '(x) + g'(x). Also, if y = f(x) - g(x), then y' = f '(x) - g'(x). These two facts may be combined: If y = f(x) g(x), then y' = f '(x)  g'(x).

    This rule may be extended to sums of finitely many terms. To see the logic of this rule, let's fall back on the definition of the derivative.

  • Composite Functions and the Chain Rule
  • When you were first introduced to the idea of mathematical functions, you may have learned to think of a function as an "input-output" machine. We put a value into the machine, (typically, x), the machine operates on this value according to a pre-determined rule and returns a value, (typically, y, or f(x)).

    For example, if our function is described by the equation, f(x) = x2, we can "feed" any real number into the "function machine" and it will return the value produced when the input number is squared. We write f(2) = 4, to indicate that the function machine returns the value 4 when the input value is 2.

    Now, suppose we consider the function f(x) = (x2 + 1)2. It is useful to think about this as two functions that act in succession. The function, x2 + 1, squares numbers and then adds 1 to them. Let's call this the inner function since it is inside the parentheses of the expression (x2 + 1)2. The value that the inner function returns is then given to the so-called outer function, which squares this value. Notice that this outer function does not get its hands on x!

    If x = 2, for example, the inner function x2 + 1 returns a 5, which the outer function promptly squares, yielding the final answer 25. The outer function doesn't square the original value of x, namely 2.

    In effect, we can visualize the process as two "function machines" acting in succession. Each value in the domain of the first function (all real numbers), is squared and then 1 is added to the result. This process produces an outcome set of real numbers greater than or equal to 1. This set now becomes the second function machine's domain (or input set), which squares each element in its domain. The final outcome set is the set of real numbers greater than or equal to one.

    Now, suppose we consider the function f(x) = (x2 + 1)2. It is useful to think about this as two functions that act in succession. The function, x2 + 1, squares numbers and then adds 1 to them. Let's call this the inner function since it is inside the parentheses of the expression (x2 + 1)2. The value that the inner function returns is then given to the so-called outer function, which squares this value. Notice that this outer function does not get its hands on x!

    If x = 2, for example, the inner function x2 + 1 returns a 5, which the outer function promptly squares, yielding the final answer 25. The outer function doesn't square the original value of x, namely 2.

    In effect, we can visualize the process as two "function machines" acting in succession. Each value in the domain of the first function (all real numbers), is squared and then 1 is added to the result. This process produces an outcome set of real numbers greater than or equal to 1. This set now becomes the second function machine's domain (or input set), which squares each element in its domain. The final outcome set is the set of real numbers greater than or equal to one.

  • Implicit Functions and Implicit Differentiation
  • The functional relationship represented by y = f(x) is an explicit one. We are told exactly how to find the value of y that corresponds to a given value of x. For example, if y = x2, then we must square a given x-value to obtain the corresponding y-value.

    On the other hand, the equation 2x + 3y = 18 merely implies a relationship between x and y. Therefore, the relationship is called implicit and we say that y is an implicit function of x. Clearly, one may solve the equation, 2x + 3y = 18 for y, yielding the explicit relationship: y = -2/3 x + 6

  • Lesson Summary
    • The Power Rule states: If f(x) = xn, where n is a positive integer, the derivative is given by f '(x) = nxn-1.
    • The multiplicative constant rule states that if y = k  f(x), then y' = k  f '(x). Sum and Difference Rule rule states that If y = f(x) g(x), then y' = f '(x) g'(x).
    • Product rule: If y = f(x) g(x), then y' = f'(x) g(x) + f(x) g'(x).

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • The derivation of f(x) = sin x is f '(x) = cos x. The derivation of f(x) = cos x is f '(x) = - sin x.
    • In effect, we can visualize the process as two "function machines" acting in succession. Each value in the domain of the first function (all real numbers), is squared and then 1 is added to the result. This process produces an outcome set of real numbers greater than or equal to 1. This set now becomes the second function machine's domain (or input set), which squares each element in its domain. The final outcome set is the set of real numbers greater than or equal to one. A function constructed this way is called a composite function.
    • If x and y are each given functions of t, then as t varies, the point (x, y) traces a curve. We call 't' a parameter, and we say that the curve is parametrized by the functions of t.
    • The equation 2x + 3y = 18 merely implies a relationship between x and y. Therefore, the relationship is called implicit and we say that y is an implicit function of x.
    • The method known as implicit differentiation enables us to calculate y' directly from the equation describing the implicit relationship between x and y.

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the derivation and application of the arcsine and the arctangent functions.
    • Describe the derivatives of logarithmic functions.
    • Outline the procedure of finding derivatives using logarithmic differentiation.
    • Analyze the applications of the derivative of in real-world problems.
    • Discuss the application and analysis of linear approximations.
    • Discuss the concept of derivatives using Newton's method and the various parts of L'Hopital's rule.
  • Arcsine Function
  • If we consider the function, y = sin x, then the inverse is formed by reversing x and y, giving us x = sin y. The means: 'y' is the angle (or arc) whose sine is 'x'.

    Thus the name, "arcsine" is given to the inverse of the sine: It is written y = arcsin x and is usually read as "y is the angle whose sine is x" although it may also be read as "y is the arc whose sine is 'x' ". This name makes sense because you may recall that in a unit circle, when we generate an angle, say theta, in real number measure (radians), it subtends an arc equal to theta.

    Another notation for the inverse sine function is y = sin-1x. This notation can be a bit problematic since the -1 denotes the inverse relationship and is not meant to be read as an exponent! The meaning is usually clear from the context.

    Another issue we encounter when we change from an x = f(y) format to the customary y = f(x) format, (y = arcsin x) is that there are infinitely many angles, (or real numbers), 'y' which satisfy the equivalent relationship x = \sin y. To make the inverse sine a legitimate function, there must be a unique value of y for any given value of x.

    Another issue we encounter when we change from an x = f(y) format to the customary y = f(x) format, (y = arcsin x) is that there are infinitely many angles, (or real numbers), 'y' which satisfy the equivalent relationship x = \sin y. To make the inverse sine a legitimate function, there must be a unique value of y for any given value of x.
  • Arcsine Function
  • If we consider the function, y = sin x, then the inverse is formed by reversing x and y, giving us x = sin y. The means: 'y' is the angle (or arc) whose sine is 'x'.

    Thus the name, "arcsine" is given to the inverse of the sine: It is written y = arcsin x and is usually read as "y is the angle whose sine is x" although it may also be read as "y is the arc whose sine is 'x' ".   • Derivatives of Logarithmic Functions: Review
  • The logarithm of x to the base b, denoted logb x, is the power, (or exponent), y, such that when b is raised to that power, we get x. In symbols: logb x = y by = x.

    Logarithms are powers. The most commonly used bases are 10 and e, (a number we shall discuss shortly). Logs using base 10 are called common logs while logs using the base e (no relation to the legendary bandleader!) are natural logs.

    The number "e" is irrational is equal to approximately 2.718 to the nearest thousandth: It is defined as follows:

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The calculus uses natural logs. We denote the natural log of x by ln x. Note that, regardless of the base of the logarithm function, logbb = 1 because this is equivalent to b1 = b. Also, regardless of the base of the logarithm function, logb1 = 0 because this is equivalent to b0 = 1.

  • Applications of the Derivative
  • Velocity, Acceleration, and Jerk
  • If the position, s, at time t, of a particle moving in a straight line is given by s = f(t), then:

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • (Jerk is what makes a person's car sick!)

    Position (s) is usually measured by selecting a point on the trajectory where s = 0, and letting s be the directed distance (positive in one direction and negative in the other) at time t from that point. It is sometimes desirable to let t = 0 at the point where s = 0. An s-axis is created to conveniently describe the motion. A falling particle, for example, will call for a vertical s-axis. 

    Note how reasonable it is that the velocity is the derivative of the position with respect to time. A moving object changes its position at a rate which is its velocity. If I travel at 55 mph, my distance from my starting point changes by 55 miles every hour.

    Position (s) is usually measured by selecting a point on the trajectory where s = 0, and letting s be the directed distance (positive in one direction and negative in the other) at time t from that point. It is sometimes desirable to let t = 0 at the point where s = 0. An s-axis is created to conveniently describe the motion. A falling particle, for example, will call for a vertical s-axis. 

    Note how reasonable it is that the velocity is the derivative of the position with respect to time. A moving object changes its position at a rate which is its velocity. If I travel at 55 mph, my distance from my starting point changes by 55 miles every hour.

  • Newton's Method
  • Suppose we wish to find the roots (or zeros) of a real-valued function, that is a solution or solutions to the equation, f(x) = 0. Suppose further that our function does not readily lend itself to previously developed methods of solution.

    Newton's Method provides us with a technique for finding the roots through successively better approximations to the x-coordinate of the point or points where our function crosses the x-axis. Another way to put this is that we wish to find the x-intercepts of the graph of y = f(x). Instead of finding a solution in one fell swoop, we shall find a sequence of values that converges to an x-intercept as follows.

    Let x1 be an initial guess. Then consider the tangent line to the curve y = f(x) at the point (x1, f(x1)).

    Its equation is:
  • y - f(x1) = f '(x1)(x - x1)
